description: Borrowed from New Latin, from Ancient Greek συστολή (sustolḗ), from συστέλλω (sustéllō, “to contract”), from σύν (sún, “together”) + στέλλω (stéllō, “to send”).

entries.meaning: (physiology) The rhythmic contraction of the heart, by which blood is driven through the arteries.
examples: A double systole catapulted him into full consciousness again, and he promised his uncorrected self that he would limit his daily ration of cigarettes to a couple of heartbeats.

entries.meaning: (prosody) A shortening of a naturally long vowel.
(mathematics) The shortest noncontractible loop on a compact metric space.
